messages.messageBody:

<swords@u...> wrote:

>

by Seki Kanemasu. Looking at Nihonto's site today I noticed Fred
has a Kanemasu tanto for sale. I own two such tanto by
Kanemasu, one having been featured as "Tanto of the Month" in
Benson's Bushido publication years ago.
>
> I find it quite curious that all of the Kanemasu tanto I've
seen--my own and others illustrated--seem to have two
mekugi-ana. One is into the Kane character and the other
centered on the nakago above the mei. It makes me wonder if
this was a happenchance of remounting or if perhaps it was
some sort of "trademark" of this smith. I'd like to find out if any
of
you own a Kanemasu and if so, how does its
nakago/menuki-ana look? Hopefully, one or two will be in your
hands.
>
> Ron
> STL
>
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

Hi Ron. on Jan 27th i posted a question on Rich Turners
Nihon-to board regarding a Katana i own signed No Shu Seki Ju
Kane Masu, I included a pic. of the Mei, only one mekugi-ana,
have a look and see what you think.
Regards Steve.

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Seki Kanemasu
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Ron, Such holes are not limited to Kanemasu, but are wide spread among Seki blades. I think it is because the original hole was thought too low for Edo
messages.messageBody:
Hi Ron,



Such holes are not limited to Kanemasu, but are wide spread among Seki
blades. I think it is because the original hole was thought too low for Edo
period mounts. I think you would need to do a comparison of Tensho period
short sword mounts and later Edo period mounts to confirm that. I might add
that it is a common complaint among collectors of Seki works in Japan, and
also adds to the problem of identifying the distinctions among the
generations if you can't fully read the kane character. There does not seem
to be the same problem with katana. This would be a good subject for a paper
Ron.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Hartmann [mailto:swords@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 03, 2004 8:17 AM
To: TOKEN; nihontostudy; nihonto@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [nihontostudy] Seki Kanemasu



Hi all -

This is directed to anybody out there who might own a sword by Seki
Kanemasu. Looking at Nihonto's site today I noticed Fred has a Kanemasu
tanto for sale. I own two such tanto by Kanemasu, one having been featured
as "Tanto of the Month" in Benson's Bushido publication years ago.

I find it quite curious that all of the Kanemasu tanto I've seen--my own and
others illustrated--seem to have two mekugi-ana. One is into the Kane
character and the other centered on the nakago above the mei. It makes me
wonder if this was a happenchance of remounting or if perhaps it was some
sort of "trademark" of this smith. I'd like to find out if any of you own a
Kanemasu and if so, how does its nakago/menuki-ana look? Hopefully, one or
two will be in your hands.

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Seki Kanemasu
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all - This is directed to anybody out there who might own a sword by Seki Kanemasu. Looking at Nihonto s site today I noticed Fred has a Kanemasu tanto for
messages.messageBody:
Hi all -

This is directed to anybody out there who might own a sword by Seki Kanemasu. Looking at Nihonto's site today I noticed Fred has a Kanemasu tanto for sale. I own two such tanto by Kanemasu, one having been featured as "Tanto of the Month" in Benson's Bushido publication years ago.

I find it quite curious that all of the Kanemasu tanto I've seen--my own and others illustrated--seem to have two mekugi-ana. One is into the Kane character and the other centered on the nakago above the mei. It makes me wonder if this was a happenchance of remounting or if perhaps it was some sort of "trademark" of this smith. I'd like to find out if any of you own a Kanemasu and if so, how does its nakago/menuki-ana look? Hopefully, one or two will be in your hands.

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
